abstract: Bear Stearns agreed to be bought by JPMorgan Chase for a bargain-basement price of less than $250 million, or about $2 a share.
snippet: Bear Stearns agreed to be bought by JPMorgan Chase for a bargain-basement price of less than $250 million, or about $2 a share.
lead_paragraph: Bear Stearns, pushed to the brink of bankruptcy by what amounted to a run on the bank, agreed late Sunday to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase for a mere $2 a share, narrowly averting a collapse that threatened to cascade through the financial system.

headline.main: JPMorgan Acts to Buy Ailing Bear Stearns at Huge Discount
headline.print_headline: JPMorgan Acts to Buy Ailing Bear Stearns at Huge Discount

byline.original: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Landon Thomas Jr

abstract: Updated 7:25 p.m. Bear Stearns, facing collapse because of the mortgage crisis, agreed Sunday evening to be bought by JPMorgan Chase for a bargain-basement price of less than $250 million, the two companies announced.
lead_paragraph: Updated 7:25 p.m. Bear Stearns, facing collapse because of the mortgage crisis, agreed Sunday evening to be bought by JPMorgan Chase for a bargain-basement price of less than $250 million, the two companies announced.

headline.main: Bear Stearns to Sell Itself to JPMorgan for $2 a Share

abstract: Update: Bear Stearns has agreed to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase for $2 a share. The firm’s shares closed at $30 on Friday, giving it a market value of $4.1 billion. For DealBook’s full coverage of the Bear Stearns crisis, go here.
lead_paragraph: Update: Bear Stearns has agreed to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase for $2 a share. The firm’s shares closed at $30 on Friday, giving it a market value of $4.1 billion. For DealBook’s full coverage of the Bear Stearns crisis, go here.

headline.main: The Cost of Bear’s Crisis to Its Employees
